div.p:
Tuesday last we left Collon
at 3, crossed the Boyne at Slane - passed the
entrance of Beauparc (whence you may recollect
we performed four years ago an aquatic excur
sionexcursion) called at Violet hill on MtMount Brabazon and
Leonora and arrived in good time at for Dinner at
Blackcastle - Mr N and his Son R. came home
at 7 from the assizes where they had been trying
the Captain Collier who you know was at
the head of a famous gang of robbers when you
were in Ireland - he had long abandoned his
predatory calling and lived in retirement, when
he was accidentally recognised by a lady his gang had
formerly robbed - This lady he had previously
known, and on her appealing to him he stepped
between her and her riffle - protected her from ill
usage and returned her everything she asked for
- All his kindness to her his counsel made
her state in a most amusing cross examination
and so great was the injunction of the jury and
indeed of the whole Court on at her ingratitude
and avarice, as the prosecution was evidently
excited by the hopes of reward on conviction, - and
so remarkable was Collier's character for generosity
and humanity as he had never done a single
cruel action and had given away large sums
to the poor that in defiance of the clearest
evidence he was actually acquitted ! - He
will not however be sent to try his hand again
on the high road as there is another charge against
him at the Westmeath assizes, and which will
probably procure him a passage to Botany bay,
- Then I suppose he will be made a useful
member of that commonwealth - probably he
will be a judge or high in some office - before
you and assume that government - Indeed
we shall have numerous acquaintance there
from the place of my birth - and Sophy R.
had begged to give me sundry letters of recommendation
from for her father's tenants -
From Navan to Kells - thence to Castle Pollard
the most dreadfully nasty place that human
imagination can conceive - no house there
now, but Mr E's new landau, the lightest and
easiest carriage I ever entered, commenced on
to Etown - on the whole I had a very pleasant
journey, the day was clear - the weather was
actually hot - the warm limestone soil had
pushed the spring far beyond that of Collon -
the birds were singing & prinking, and at Etown
I met the warmest & kindest welcome -
nothing, the whole party said was wanted to
make them happy but your having accompanied
me - Mr E. is shockingly reduced indeed,
in flesh in strength in activity in everything
but the vigour and clearness of his mind which
is undiminished - Fanny and the other elders
all in statu quo - Fan and the youngsters are
prodigiously improved indeed - Harriet quite
softened and polished, the constant and tender
nurse of her father - Sophy the quaker grown large and
very pretty sedate and mild and sensible -
Lucy tall, very like Fan, her memory strong, her
powers of mind opened and in every way doing justice
to my prognostics - Francis has lost his little pedantic
stiffness, is as playful as a kitten and as intel
ligentintelligent and quick as any of the theoretic personages
of Prac. Ed. - Pakenham is in breeches and the
sweetest mildest little fellow (next to DAB & Francis)
in the world - I now saw such an engaging
picture of union and happiness as the whole
circle - some unpleasant reflections now and
then flit across their brows at the state of their
the master and centre of the circle - but you
know the constant employment and activity here
leaves but little time for melancholy apprehension,
- Mr E. dictates the longest letters without hesitation
listens to reading - directs his modellists and
gimcrack makers - and feels his way about
the house, all with the same precision as he
did twenty years ago when his piercing little eyes
and harlequin limbs were in their prime - And
yet every night his stomach rejects his food,
from daylight till noon he is constantly reaching
and in the greatest pain - and his sight is so
exhausted that he can hardly stick his fork
in the bit of meat he cuts! - Friday he and
I went to Longford to examine the bridge which
William is to rebuild - Yesterday Saturday we went
to Lisney to inspect a new road - and today
we have been making a model for a new fashioned
bridge
bridge. In truth he is a most extraordinary
man - Maria is hard at work on 3 vol
of tales which will make their appearance in
June - (her dramas are already in the press)
- her father is pressing her hard as he earnestly
wishes to see this one more work out before
he dies! - The subject occasion of one of the tales is curious - Maria a year ago received a letter from a very sensible woman in America expressing the her admiration of the works and containing some excellent observations - but gently reporting her with having in no instance mentioned a Jew without branding him with all the common- -place acrimony of vulgar writers - "Yet" says the fair Israelite writer "can it be believed that this race of men are by Nature mean avaricious and unprincipled? - Forbid it Mercy! In those parts of the world where the people are oppressed and the continual subjects of scorn and derision they may in too many instances draw censure: but in this happy country where religious distinctions are unknown
- & when character and talents are sufficient to attain advancement in kind the Jews form a respectable part of the community. They are as liberal and well educated as others - they follow the honourable professions of the Law, Physick &c with credit and ability, and associate with the best society. Friendships and attachments are formed with thou of different persuasions from their own, and each looks on the variations of the other as things of course - as differences which necessarily take place in every society." - And much more in another letter - In consequence Maria has composed a story on purpose to place a Jew in a more favourable point of view. Madame de Staël's new work will possibly make its appearance about the same time - She offered it to Murray at the extravagant price of 4000 Guineas - which was of course rejected, but I understand the negociation has been renewed - The Baroness has chosen but an unpromising title, at least a for this country - the public seem quite sick of cause
and effect. It will be "Sur les causes et les effects de la Revolution Francaise" - The English French recollection is a threadbare subject in this country - but there is an episode which will stimulate the curiosity of a large portion of readers - "L'Angleterre" - So rarely have philosophers deigned to travel in England, (and of those none of any note have published their observations unless Pillote &e.) -) that it will be very interesting to look in the glass, though shaped and polished by hands not quite free from prejudice - Madme de Stael saw a great deal of Lord Byron last summer at Copet - with the questi- oning licence of literary ladies she asked him whether he had read Glenavon, and if he thought it a good likeness - He replied "Le portrait aurait ete plus resemblant de j'avais donne plus de seances." - Talking of Lord Byron, I may add that one of Marie's correspondents, says that since his residence at Genova he appears to be dwindling into a mere imitation of the Lake poets. This
corresponding gentn says he had been much amused by reading his lordship's journal thro' Switzerland in which are many detached expressions characteristic of the poet and of the man. - Among them is a curious description of a great cascade 900 feet high that carves in falling over a rock: - he says its shape is like "the Tail of a white horse streaming in the wind, such as might be conceived would be that of the Pale Horse on which Death is mounted in the Apocalypse neither mist nor water but something between both, wonderful & indescribable." One of the Glaciers he called a frozen hurricane. He quits the mountains with regret, and says "my journal will now be as flat as the country we traverse: from Thum to Berne we had good roads, good houses, property and all the commonplace tokens of insipid civilization. It can does not appear to be true that Ld B. and his lady have any design of being again reconciled - I saw a letter this morning from
from a friend of hers - deprecating the insidious efforts made in his late poems to detract the affections of the son from his mother as he grows up - plots for such distant operations certainly do not look like reunion at present. The writer of the letter also says that Lady B. has recovered the roses and cheerfulness which she had entirely lost which with her husband - The Mr Synge you mention is father of the translator of one of Pestalozzi's little works and will probably tell you when you can purchase a copy. Lovell's school proceeds very well the change in manners and application of all the poor boys about the town is astonishing, and if he persevers, the effect here and wherever he may be imitated will have a material influence on the character of this country - I never look at one of these schools without Poor Lowell is still in Dublin under the hands of Crampton & has been obliged to submit to a second operation after 3 in in be right - the sinus running under the cartilige of his ribs
feeling how much good an active and philanthropic enthusiast may do - and still more deeply feeling that in tying you to a man of my confined circum- stances I have robbed society of an agent who is married to a country gentleman in a more flourishing way might have dispensed the real blessings of Providence to miles around you It is now time to reply to your long and interesting letter of the 4th which I found here - Your account of D. & F. was satisfactory - Would to God that you could have equally gratified me about poor A. - I have been endeavouring to obtain some knowledge respecting the disease of Cataract which he seems to clearly to have - in order to make up my mind as to the propriety of early or late operation - the first thing I shall do on my return to London will be to consult some of the best occulists - in
the mean time it would do no harm if you were to let Mr Each examine it - & I do not see why you should object to it - provided always that the Griffith's may not be amazed - but they need not be told. - Are you sure that he sees with the right eye? - The great Point to ascertain just now, is what part of the eye is reflected, as Cataracts occur in the capsule, the lens &c - There is one little favour I would ask at your hands - not to read any thing on the subject learn as much as you canlike in conversation but read none - My reasons need not now be explained, but there are reasons. The genuflexion which your Aunt Peach requires seems to amuse you - on the contrary I am seriously alarmed - because such a speech to Selina appears to me to proceed from a species of weakness or folly so nearly bordering on insanity, which acted
upon by the art and cunning of the people who govern her may form a source of the bitterest uneasiness and misery to your dear and very different mother as long as she lives. - As far as regards Selina the effect may be salutary - and I would earnestly advise, that both her sisters may take advantage of the momentary revulsion produced on her mind, and by kindness (and apparent confidence in trifles which is of all things the most winning to people of her disposition) convince her that in the bosom of her own family and she will have the first charm of disinterested affection & friendship. - In truth Selina has per se an excellent heart, and needs only to be gradually (but not too apparently) strengthened - confidence in her (prudently administered) will have the only chance of inducing preventing her to seeking a recipient for her's out of doors - Give her a kiss for me. and
And hers dear Henrietta also - In Dublin Collon nor in this highly gifted bevy of girls do I find a single sister or relation who is more truly amiable than she is, nor one who I more truly love. - I really am very sorry for the story of the White Ass - You see how malice can lend even wit to Folly - I solemnly declare I had no such meaning in my question - - Whatever I think of the sapiency of Mrs. S. Peach, she surely is one of the last persons that I would voluntarily insult - she is the wife of your father's old friend - Besides there would have been so much coarseness in the idea that I am sure if the idea it had even ocurred[choice]occured[/choice] to my imagination I should not have had resolution to have brought it out. All here join in sincere affection to you and by to be particularly remembered to some , and none more warmly than Aunt Mary. Remember them also to the Griffiths' and bless me my dear widowed wife Your
